page.title: 12PLACE NAMES.
page.content: The Holegate part of Halton Holegate comes from the 'Hollowgate'. There is a deep cutting in the sandstone and the road to Firsby runs through the gap.A wooden footbridge linked the Rectory and the Church. Older people in the village leave out the "e" in Holegate and spell it Holgate. Northorpe Road which leaves the village to the north took its name from the original name of the village. This shows the influence of the Danes in the area, as does Spilsby, the name of the small market town in the north west corner of our area. Our school stands in Station Road. Beverley House where Mr. Clough lives gets its name from the fact that this house and some land in Halton was owned by the Beverley Grammar School. Peasgate Lane: originally all the roads leaving the villages were gates.
